aac.description: Advanced Audio Coding format, designed to be the successor format to MP3, with generally better sound quality.
aac.notes: Support refers to using the `audio` element, not other conditions.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to only supporting AAC in an MP4 container and only when the operating system already has the codecs installed.

aac.title: AAC audio file format

addeventlistener.description: The modern standard API for adding DOM event handlers. Introduced in the DOM Level 2 Events spec. Also implies support for the [capture phase](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-event-capturing_phase) of DOM event dispatch and `preventDefault()`.

notes_by_num.1: IE<=8 instead only supports the [proprietary `.attachEvent()` method](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms536343%28VS.85%29.aspx). It also does not support the [capture phase](http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/#event-flow) of DOM event dispatch; it only supports event bubbling.
notes_by_num.2: The `useCapture` parameter is non-optional and must be provided. Future versions made it optional, with a default value of `false`.

addeventlistener.title: EventTarget.addEventListener()

ambient-light.description: Defines events that provide information about the ambient light level, as measured by a device's light sensor.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in desktop Firefox refers to support being limited to Mac OS X. [Support for Windows 7 is in progress](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=754199)

ambient-light.title: Ambient Light API

apng.description: Like animated GIFs, but allowing 24-bit colors and alpha transparency

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

apng.notes: Where support for APNG is missing, only the first frame is displayed
apng.title: Animated PNG (APNG)

arrow-functions.description: Function shorthand using `=>` syntax and lexical `this` binding.
arrow-functions.title: Arrow functions

asmjs.description: an extraordinarily optimizable, low-level subset of JavaScript, indended to be a compile target from languages like C++.

links.title: Bringing Asm.js to Chakra and Microsoft Edge

notes_by_num.1: Chrome does not support Ahead-Of-Time compilation but performance doubled in Chrome 28: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asm.js#Implementations
notes_by_num.2: Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable experimental Javascript features" flag.

asmjs.title: asm.js

atob-btoa.description: Utility functions for of encoding and decoding strings to and from base 64: window.atob() and window.btoa().
atob-btoa.title: Base64 encoding and decoding

audio.description: Method of playing sound on webpages (without requiring a plug-in).

links.title: Demos of audio player that uses the audio element

audio.title: Audio element

audio-api.description: High-level JavaScript API for processing and synthesizing audio

links.title: Polyfill to support Web Audio API in Firefox
Additional browser compatibility tests for specific features
Polyfill to enable Web Audio API through Firefox Audio Data api or flash

audio-api.notes:
Not all browsers with support for the Audio API also support media streams (e.g. microphone input). See the [getUserMedia/Streams API](/#feat=stream) data for support for that feature.

Firefox versions < 25 support an alternative, deprecated audio API.

Chrome support [went through some changes](http://updates.html5rocks.com/2014/07/Web-Audio-Changes-in-m36) as of version 36.
audio-api.title: Web Audio API

audiotracks.description: Method of specifying and selecting between multiple audio tracks. Useful for providing audio descriptions, director's commentary, additional languages, alternative takes, etc.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox by enabling "media.track.enabled" in about:config

audiotracks.title: Audio Tracks

autofocus.description: Allows a form field to be immediately focused on page load.
autofocus.notes: While not supported in iOS Safari, it does work in iOS WebViews.
autofocus.title: Autofocus attribute

background-attachment.description: Method of defining how a background image is attached to a scrollable element. Values include `scroll` (default), `fixed` and `local`.
background-attachment.notes: Most mobile devices have a delay in updating the background position after scrolling a page with `fixed` backgrounds.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting `fixed` but not `local`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting `local` but not `fixed`
notes_by_num.3: Only supports `local` when `-webkit-overflow-scrolling: touch` is _not_ used
notes_by_num.4: Does not support `fixed`, and due [to a bug](https://crbug.com/627037) only supports `local` if a `border-radius` is set on the element.

background-attachment.title: CSS background-attachment

background-img-opts.description: New properties to affect background images, including background-clip, background-origin and background-size
background-img-opts.notes: Safari also supports the unofficial `-webkit-background-clip: text` (only with prefix)

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Opera Mini refers to not supporting background sizing or background attachments. However Opera Mini 7.5 supports background sizing (including cover and contain values).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari 6 refers to not supporting background sizing offset from edges syntax.
notes_by_num.3: Does not support `background-size` values in the `background` shorthand

background-img-opts.title: CSS3 Background-image options

background-position-x-y.description: CSS longhand properties to define x or y positions separately.

links.title: Blog post on background-position-x & y properties

background-position-x-y.notes: A workaround for the lack of support in Firefox 31 - Firefox 48 is to use [CSS variables](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Using_CSS_variables). See [this Stack Overflow answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/29282573/94197) for an example.
background-position-x-y.title: background-position-x & background-position-y

battery-status.description: Method to provide information about the battery status of the hosting device.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to support for the older specification's `navigator.battery` rather than `navigator.getBattery()` to access the `BatteryManager`.

battery-status.title: Battery Status API

beacon.description: Allows data to be sent asynchronously to a server with `navigator.sendBeacon`, even after a page was closed. Useful for posting analytics data the moment a user was finished using the page.
beacon.title: Beacon API

blobbuilder.description: Construct Blobs (binary large objects) either using the BlobBuilder API (deprecated) or the Blob constructor.
blobbuilder.notes: Partial support refers to only supporting the now deprecated BlobBuilder to create blobs.
blobbuilder.title: Blob constructing

bloburls.description: Method of creating URL handles to the specified File or Blob object.
bloburls.title: Blob URLs

border-image.description: Method of using images for borders
border-image.notes: Note that both the `border-style` and `border-width` must be specified (not set to `none` or 0) for border-images to work.

notes_by_num.1: Has a bug where `border-image` incorrectly overrides `border-style`. See [test case](http://codepen.io/Savago/pen/yYrgyK), [WebKit bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=99922), [discussion](https://github.com/whatwg/compat/issues/17)
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `border-image-repeat: space`
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to supporting the shorthand syntax, but not the individual properties (`border-image-source`, `border-image-slice`, etc).
notes_by_num.4: Partial support refers to not supporting `border-image-repeat: round`

border-image.title: CSS3 Border images

border-radius.description: Method of making the border corners round. Covers support for the shorthand `border-radius` as well as the long-hand properties (e.g. `border-top-left-radius`)

notes_by_num.1: Safari 6.1 and earlier did not apply `border-radius` correctly to image borders: http://stackoverflow.com/q/17202128

border-radius.title: CSS3 Border-radius (rounded corners)

broadcastchannel.description: BroadcastChannel allows scripts from the same origin but other browsing contexts (windows, workers) to send each other messages.
broadcastchannel.title: BroadcastChannel

brotli.description: More effective lossless compression algorithm than gzip and deflate.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Chrome and Opera behind the 'Brotli Content-Encoding' flag
notes_by_num.2: Enabled since 27 May 2016

brotli.title: Brotli Accept-Encoding/Content-Encoding

calc.description: Method of allowing calculated values for length units, i.e. `width: calc(100% - 3em)`
calc.notes:
Support can be somewhat emulated in older versions of IE using the non-standard `expression()` syntax.

Due to the way browsers handle [sub-pixel rounding](http://ejohn.org/blog/sub-pixel-problems-in-css/) differently, layouts using `calc()` expressions may have unexpected results.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android Browser 4.4 refers to the browser lacking the ability to multiply and divide values.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE9 refers to the browser crashing when used as a `background-position` value.

calc.title: calc() as CSS unit value

canvas.description: Method of generating fast, dynamic graphics using JavaScript.
canvas.notes:
For screen readers, IE, Chrome & Firefox support the [accessible canvas element sub-DOM](http://www.paciellogroup.com/blog/2012/06/html5-canvas-accessibility-in-firefox-13/).
Firefox & Chrome also support the drawfocus ring.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `toDataURL()`
notes_by_num.2: Opera Mini supports the canvas element, but is unable to play animations or run other more complex applications.

canvas.title: Canvas (basic support)

canvas-blending.description: Method of defining the effect resulting from overlaying two layers on a Canvas element.
canvas-blending.title: Canvas blend modes

canvas-text.description: Method of displaying text on Canvas elements
canvas-text.title: Text API for Canvas

ch-unit.description: Unit representing the width of the character "0" in the current font, of particular use in combination with monospace fonts.

links.title: Blog post on using ch units

notes_by_num.1: IE supports the `ch` unit, but unlike other browsers its width is that specifically of the "0" glyph, not its surrounding space. As a result, 3ch for example is shorter in than the width of the string "000" in IE.

ch-unit.title: ch (character) unit

chacha20-poly1305.description: A set of cipher suites used in Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol, using ChaCha20 for symmetric encryption and Poly1305 for authentication.

links.title: SSL/TLS Capabilities of Your Browser by Qualys SSL Labs
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Old versions of Chrome use non-standard code points for ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher suites.

chacha20-poly1305.title: ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher suites for TLS

channel-messaging.description: Method for having two-way communication between browsing contexts (using MessageChannel)

links.title: An Introduction to HTML5 web messaging

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `dom.messageChannel.enabled` flag. Reported to not work in web workers before version 41.

channel-messaging.title: Channel messaging

classlist.description: Method of easily manipulating classes on elements, using the DOMTokenList object.

notes_by_num.1: Does not have support for `classList` on SVG or MathML elements.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the second parameter for the `toggle` method
notes_by_num.3: Does not support multiple parameters for the `add()` & `remove()` methods

classlist.title: classList (DOMTokenList)

client-hints-dpr-width-viewport.description: DPR, Width, and Viewport-Width hints enable proactive content negotiation between client and server, enabling automated delivery of optimized assets - e.g. auto-negotiating image DPR resolution.
client-hints-dpr-width-viewport.keywords: client hints, client-hints, dpr, viewport, content-dpr

links.title: Automating resource selection with Client Hints
Mozilla Bug 935216 - Implement Client-Hints HTTP header
WebKit Bug 145380 - Add Content-DPR header support
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

client-hints-dpr-width-viewport.title: Client Hints: DPR, Width, Viewport-Width

clipboard.description: API to provide copy, cut and paste events as well as provide access to the OS clipboard.
clipboard.notes:
Internet Explorer will display a security prompt for access to the OS clipboard.

Chrome 42+, Opera 29+ and Firefox 41+ support clipboard reading/writing only when part of a user action (click, keydown, etc).

Firefox 40- users [can enable support](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Midas/Security_preferences) with a security preference setting.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports `Text` and `URL` data types and uses [a non-standard method](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/ms535220%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) of interacting with the clipboard.
notes_by_num.2: Only fires `copy` event on a valid selection and only `cut` and `paste` in focused editable fields.
notes_by_num.3: Only supports OS clipboard reading/writing via shortcut keys, not through `document.execCommand()`.
notes_by_num.4: Only supports `paste` event (on focused editable field).
notes_by_num.6: Supports `cut` & `copy` events without a focused editable field, but not `paste` (presumably for security reasons)
notes_by_num.7: Supports `cut` & `copy` events without a focused editable field, but does not fire `paste` with `document.execCommand('paste')`

clipboard.title: Clipboard API

console-basic.description: Method of outputting data to the browser's console, intended for development purposes.
console-basic.notes: The basic functions that this information refers to include `console.log`, `console.info`, `console.warn`, `console.error`.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports console functions when developer tools are open, otherwise the `console` object is undefined and any calls will throw errors.
notes_by_num.2: Allows `console` functions to be used without throwing errors, but does not appear to output the data anywhere.
notes_by_num.3: Log output on iOS 6+ Safari can only be seen by connecting to a Mac and using the [Safari debugger](https://developer.apple.com/safari/tools/).
notes_by_num.4: Log output on older Android browsers can be retrieved via Android's `logcat` command or using Chrome Developer Tools in Android 4.4+/Chrome for Android [see details](http://developer.android.com/guide/webapps/debugging.html)
notes_by_num.5: Log output on Firefox for Android can be [accessed using WebIDE](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Tools/Remote_Debugging/Debugging_Firefox_for_Android_with_WebIDE)
notes_by_num.6: See [this article](https://dev.opera.com/articles/opera-mini-and-javascript/) for details on how to see console logging in Opera Mini

console-basic.title: Basic console logging functions

const.description: Declares a constant with block level scope

notes_by_num.1: const is recognized, but treated like var (no block scope, can be overwritten)
notes_by_num.2: const does not have block scope
notes_by_num.3: Only recognized when NOT in strict mode
notes_by_num.4: Supported correctly in strict mode, otherwise supported without block scope

const.title: const

contenteditable.description: Method of making any HTML element editable.
contenteditable.notes: This support only refers to very basic editing capability, implementations vary significantly on how certain elements can be edited.
contenteditable.title: contenteditable attribute (basic support)

contentsecuritypolicy.description: Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by whitelisting allowed sources of script, style, and other resources.
contentsecuritypolicy.notes: The standard HTTP header is `Content-Security-Policy` which is used unless otherwise noted.

notes_by_num.1: Supported through the `X-Content-Security-Policy` header
notes_by_num.2: Supported through the `X-Webkit-CSP` header

contentsecuritypolicy.title: Content Security Policy 1.0

contentsecuritypolicy2.description: Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by whitelisting allowed sources of script, style, and other resources. CSP 2 adds hash-source, nonce-source, and five new directives

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 31-34 is missing the plugin-types, child-src, frame-ancestors, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox 35 is missing the plugin-types, child-src, frame-ancestors, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.3: Firefox 36-44 is missing the plugin-types and child-src directives.
notes_by_num.4: Chrome 36-38 & Opera 23-25 are missing the plugin-types, child-src, frame-ancestors, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.5: Chrome 39 and Opera 26 are missing the plugin-types, child-src, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.6: Firefox 38 on Android is missing the child-src directive.
notes_by_num.7: Firefox 45+ is missing the plugin-types directive.

contentsecuritypolicy2.title: Content Security Policy Level 2

cors.description: Method of performing XMLHttpRequests across domains

notes_by_num.1: Does not support CORS for images in `<canvas>`
notes_by_num.2: Supported somewhat in IE8 and IE9 using the XDomainRequest object (but has [limitations](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/05/13/xdomainrequest-restrictions-limitations-and-workarounds.aspx))
notes_by_num.3: Does not support CORS for `<video>` in `<canvas>`: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=135379

cors.title: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing

cryptography.description: JavaScript API for performing basic cryptographic operations in web applications

links.title: The History and Status of Web Crypto API
Support for recommended algorithms in Firefox
Polyfill by Netflix with partial support
PKI.js - another crypto library for Public Key Infrastructure applications
Web Cryptography API shim for IE11 and Safari - set of bugfixes and workarounds of prefixed api implementations

cryptography.notes:
Many browsers support the `[crypto.getRandomValues()](#feat=getrandomvalues)` method, but not actual cryptography functionality under `crypto.subtle`. 

Firefox also has support for [unofficial features](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/JavaScript_crypto). 

In Chrome the API is only usable over secure connections. ([corresponding bug](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=373032))

notes_by_num.1: Support in IE11 is based an older version of the specification.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Firefox behind the `dom.webcrypto.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.3: Supported in Safari using the `crypto.webkitSubtle` prefix.

cryptography.title: Web Cryptography

css-all.description: A shorthand property for resetting all CSS properties except for `direction` and `unicode-bidi`.

links.title: WebKit bug 116966: [css3-cascade] Add support for `all` shorthand property
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-all.title: CSS all property

css-animation.description: Complex method of animating certain properties of an element

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android browser refers to buggy behavior in different scenarios.

css-animation.title: CSS Animation

css-appearance.description: The `appearance` property defines how elements (particularly form controls) appear by default. By setting the value to `none` the default appearance can be entirely redefined using other CSS properties.

notes_by_num.1: The appearance property is supported with the `none` value, but not `auto`. Webkit, Blink, and Gecko browsers also support additional vendor specific values.
notes_by_num.2: Microsoft Edge and IE Mobile support this property with the `-webkit-` prefix, rather than `-ms-` for interop reasons.

css-appearance.title: CSS Appearance

css-at-counter-style.description: The @counter-style CSS at-rule allows custom counter styles to be defined. A @counter-style rule defines how to convert a counter value into a string representation.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to lacking support for [image symbols](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1024179)

css-at-counter-style.title: CSS Counter Styles

css-backdrop-filter.description: Method of applying filter effects (like blur, grayscale or hue) to content/elements below the target element.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag

css-backdrop-filter.title: CSS Backdrop Filter

css-background-offsets.description: Allows CSS background images to be positioned relative to the specified edge using the 3 to 4 value syntax. For example: `background-position: right 5px bottom 5px;` for positioning 5px from the bottom-right corner.
css-background-offsets.title: CSS background-position edge offsets

css-backgroundblendmode.description: Allows blending between CSS background images, gradients, and colors.

notes_by_num.1: Partial in Safari refers to not supporting the `hue`, `saturation`, `color`, and `luminosity` blend modes.
notes_by_num.2: Chrome 46 has some [serious bugs](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=543583) with multiply, difference, and exclusion blend modes

css-backgroundblendmode.title: CSS background-blend-mode

css-boxdecorationbreak.description: Controls whether the box's margins, borders, padding, and other decorations wrap the broken edges of the box fragments (when the box is split by a break (page/column/region/line).

links.title: Demo of effect on box border
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to working for inline elements but not across column or page breaks.

css-boxdecorationbreak.title: CSS box-decoration-break

css-boxshadow.description: Method of displaying an inner or outer shadow effect to elements
css-boxshadow.notes: Can be partially emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "shadow" filter.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Safari, iOS Safari and Android Browser refers to missing "inset", blur radius value, and multiple shadow support.

css-boxshadow.title: CSS3 Box-shadow

css-canvas.description: Method of using HTML5 Canvas as a background image. Not currently part of any specification.
css-canvas.notes: A similar effect can be achieved in Firefox 4+ using the -moz-element() background property
css-canvas.title: CSS Canvas Drawings

css-case-insensitive.description: Including an `i` before the `]` in a CSS attribute selector causes the attribute value to be matched in an ASCII-case-insensitive manner. For example, `[b="xyz" i]` would match both `<a b="xyz">` and `<a b="XYZ">`.
css-case-insensitive.title: Case-insensitive CSS attribute selectors

css-clip-path.description: Method of defining the visible region of an element using SVG or a shape definition.

links.title: Codepen Example Clipping an Image with a Polygon

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting the `url()` syntax.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting shapes and the `url(#foo)` syntax for inline SVG, but not shapes in external SVGs.
notes_by_num.3: Supports shapes behind the `layout.css.clip-path-shapes.enabled` flag

css-clip-path.title: CSS clip-path property

css-containment.description: The CSS `contain` property lets developers limit the scope of the browser's styles, layout and paint work for faster and more efficient rendering.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag

css-containment.title: CSS Containment

css-counters.description: Method of controlling number values in generated content, using the `counter-reset` and `counter-increment` properties.
css-counters.title: CSS Counters

css-crisp-edges.description: Scales images with an algorithm that preserves edges and contrast, without smoothing colors or introducing blur. This is intended for images such as pixel art. Official values that accomplish this for the `image-rendering` property are `crisp-edges` and `pixelated`.
css-crisp-edges.notes: Note that prefixes apply to the value (e.g. `-moz-crisp-edges`), not the `image-rendering` property.

notes_by_num.1: Supported using the non-standard value `-webkit-optimize-contrast`
notes_by_num.2: Internet Explorer accomplishes support using the non-standard declaration `-ms-interpolation-mode: nearest-neighbor`
notes_by_num.3: Supports the `crisp-edges` value, but not `pixelated`.
notes_by_num.4: Supports the `pixelated` value, but not `crisp-edges`.
notes_by_num.5: Only works on ``, not CSS backgrounds or ``.
notes_by_num.6: Only works on `` and CSS backgrounds, _not_ ``.

css-crisp-edges.title: Crisp edges/pixelated images

css-cross-fade.description: Image function to create a "crossfade" between images. This allows one image to transition (fade) into another based on a percentage value.
css-cross-fade.title: CSS Cross-Fade Function

css-default-pseudo.description: The `:default` pseudo-class matches checkboxes and radio buttons which are checked by default, `<option>`s with the `selected` attribute, and the default submit button (if any) of a form.

links.title: MS Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit bug 156230 - `:default` CSS pseudo-class should match checkboxes+radios with a `checked` attribute

css-default-pseudo.notes: Whether `<option selected>` matches `:default` (per the spec) was not tested since `<select>`s and `<option>`s are generally not styleable, which makes it hard to formulate a test for this.

notes_by_num.1: Does not match `<input type="checkbox" checked>` or `<input type="radio" checked>`
notes_by_num.2: Does not match the default submit button of a form

css-default-pseudo.title: :default CSS pseudo-class

css-descendant-gtgt.description: An explicit, non-whitespace spelling of the descendant combinator. `A >> B` is equivalent to `A B`.

links.title: Mozilla bug #1266283 - Implement CSS4 descendant combinator `>>`

css-descendant-gtgt.title: Explicit descendant combinator >>

css-deviceadaptation.description: A standard way to override the size of viewport in web page using the `@viewport` rule, standardizing and replacing Apple's own popular `<meta>` viewport implementation.

links.title: Introduction to meta viewport and @viewport in Opera Mobile
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: IE only supports the 'width' and 'height' properties.
notes_by_num.2: Opera Mobile and Opera Mini only support the 'orientation' property.

css-deviceadaptation.title: CSS Device Adaptation

css-dir-pseudo.description: Matches elements based on their directionality. `:dir(ltr)` matches elements which are Left-to-Right. `:dir(rtl)` matches elements which are Right-to-Left.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit bug #64861: Need support for :dir() pseudo-class

css-dir-pseudo.title: :dir() CSS pseudo-class

css-element-function.description: This function renders a live image generated from an arbitrary HTML element

notes_by_num.1: In Firefox < 4, usage limited to the background and background-image CSS properties

css-element-function.title: CSS element() function

css-exclusions.description: Exclusions defines how inline content flows around elements. It extends the content wrapping ability of floats to any block-level element.
css-exclusions.title: CSS Exclusions Level 1

css-featurequeries.description: CSS Feature Queries allow authors to condition rules based on whether particular property declarations are supported in CSS using the @supports at rule.
css-featurequeries.title: CSS Feature Queries

css-filter-function.description: This function filters a CSS input image with a set of filter functions (like blur, grayscale or hue)
css-filter-function.title: CSS filter() function

css-filters.description: Method of applying filter effects (like blur, grayscale, brightness, contrast and hue) to elements, previously only possible by using SVG.
css-filters.notes: Note that this property is significantly different from and incompatible with Microsoft's [older "filter" property](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/ms530752%28v=vs.85%29.aspx).

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox under the `layout.css.filters.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable CSS filter property" flag.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox before version 34 [only implemented the url() function of the filter property](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/filter#Browser_compatibility)
notes_by_num.4: Partial support refers to supporting filter functions, but not the `url` function.

css-filters.title: CSS Filter Effects

css-first-letter.description: CSS pseudo-element that allows styling only the first "letter" of text within an element. Useful for implementing initial caps or drop caps styling.
css-first-letter.notes: The spec says that both letters of digraphs which are always capitalized together (such as "IJ" in Dutch) should be matched by ::first-letter, but no browser has ever implemented this.

notes_by_num.1: Excludes punctuation immediately after the first letter from the match. (The spec says it should be included in the match.)
notes_by_num.2: Acts like the first character is always a letter even when it's not. For example, given "!,X;", "!," is matched instead of the entire string.
notes_by_num.3: Only recognizes the deprecated :first-letter pseudo-class, not the ::first-letter pseudo-element.
notes_by_num.4: Only matches the very first character. The spec says that surrounding punctuation should also match.

css-first-letter.title: ::first-letter CSS pseudo-element selector

css-fixed.description: Method of keeping an element in a fixed location regardless of scroll position

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older iOS Safari refers to [buggy behavior](http://remysharp.com/2012/05/24/issues-with-position-fixed-scrolling-on-ios/).
notes_by_num.2: Only works in Android 2.1 thru 2.3 by using the following meta tag: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, user-scalable=no">.

css-fixed.title: CSS position:fixed

css-focus-within.description: The `:focus-within` pseudo-class matches elements that either themselves match `:focus` or that have descendants which match `:focus`.

links.title: The Future Generation of CSS Selectors: Level 4: Generalized Input Focus Pseudo-class
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit bug #140144: Add support for CSS4 `:focus-within` pseudo
Chromium issue #617371: Implement `:focus-within` pseudo-class from Selectors Level 4
Mozilla bug #1176997: Add support for pseudo class `:focus-within`

css-focus-within.title: :focus-within CSS pseudo-class

css-font-stretch.description: If a font has multiple types of variations based on the width of characters, the `font-stretch` property allows the appropriate one to be selected. The property in itself does not cause the browser to stretch to a font.
css-font-stretch.title: CSS font-stretch

css-gencontent.description: Method of displaying text or images before or after the given element's contents using the ::before and ::after pseudo-elements. All browsers with support also support the `attr()` notation in the `content` property.
css-gencontent.notes: For content to appear in pseudo-elements, the `content` property must be set (but may be an empty string).

notes_by_num.1: IE8 only supports the single-colon CSS 2.1 syntax (i.e. :pseudo-class). It does not support the double-colon CSS3 syntax (i.e. ::pseudo-element).

css-gencontent.title: CSS Generated content for pseudo-elements

css-gradients.description: Method of defining a linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.

links.title: Tool to emulate support in IE

css-gradients.notes:
Syntax used by browsers with prefixed support may be incompatible with that for proper support.

Support can be somewhat emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "gradient" filter. 

Firefox 10+, Opera 11.6+, Chrome 26+ and IE10+ also support the new "to (side)" syntax.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Opera 11.10 and 11.50 also refers to only having support for linear gradients.

css-gradients.title: CSS Gradients

css-grid.description: Method of using a grid concept to lay out content, providing a mechanism for authors to divide available space for lay out into columns and rows using a set of predictable sizing behaviors
css-grid.notes:
Supported in WebKit Nightly with `-webkit-` prefix.

Enabled by default in Firefox nightly and developer editions, but not yet on track to be enabled in beta or stable Firefox.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to supporting an [older version](http://www.w3.org/TR/2011/WD-css3-grid-layout-20110407/) of the specification.
notes_by_num.3: Enabled in Firefox through the `layout.css.grid.enabled ` flag

css-grid.title: CSS Grid Layout

css-has.description: Only select elements containing specified content. For example, `a:has(>img)` selects all `` elements that contain an `` child.
css-has.title: :has() CSS relational pseudo-class

css-hyphens.description: Method of controlling when words at the end of lines should be hyphenated using the "hyphens" property.
css-hyphens.notes: Chrome and Android 4.0 Browser support "-webkit-hyphens: none", but not the "auto" property. It is [advisable to set the @lang attribute](http://blog.adrianroselli.com/2015/01/on-use-of-lang-attribute.html) on the HTML element to enable hyphenation support and improve accessibility.
css-hyphens.title: CSS Hyphenation

css-image-orientation.description: CSS property used generally to fix the intended orientation of an image. This can be done using 90 degree increments or based on the image's EXIF data using the "from-image" value.
css-image-orientation.notes: Opening the image in a new tab in Chrome results in the image shown in the orientation according to the EXIF data.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in iOS refers to the browser using EXIF data by default, though it does not actually support the property.

css-image-orientation.title: CSS3 image-orientation

css-image-set.description: Method of letting the browser pick the most appropriate CSS background image from a given set, primarily for high PPI screens.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-image-set.title: CSS image-set

css-in-out-of-range.description: If a temporal or number `<input>` has `max` and/or `min` attributes, then `:in-range` matches when the value is within the specified range and `:out-of-range` matches when the value is outside the specified range. If there are no range constraints, then neither pseudo-class matches.
css-in-out-of-range.notes: Note that `<input type="range">` can never match `:out-of-range` because the user cannot input such a value, and if the initial value is outside the range, the browser immediately clamps it to the minimum or maximum (as appropriate) bound of the range.

notes_by_num.1: Opera Mini correctly applies style on initial load, but does not correctly update when value is changed.
notes_by_num.2: `:in-range` also incorrectly matches temporal and `number` inputs which don't have `min` or `max` attributes. See [Edge bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/7200501/), [Chrome bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=603268), [WebKit bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=156558).
notes_by_num.3: `:in-range` and `:out-of-range` incorrectly match inputs which are disabled or readonly. See [Mozilla bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1264157), [WebKit bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=156530), [Chrome bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=602568).

css-in-out-of-range.title: :in-range and :out-of-range CSS pseudo-classes

css-indeterminate-pseudo.description: The `:indeterminate` pseudo-class matches indeterminate checkboxes, indeterminate `<progress>` bars, and radio buttons with no checked button in their radio button group.

links.title: EdgeHTML issue 7124038 - `:indeterminate` pseudo-class doesn't match radio buttons
Mozilla Bug 885359 - Radio groups without a selected radio button should have `:indeterminate` applying
WebKit Bug 156270 - `:indeterminate` pseudo-class should match radios whose group has no checked radio

notes_by_num.1: Doesn't match radio buttons whose radio button group lacks a checked radio button
notes_by_num.2: Doesn't support the `<progress>` element
notes_by_num.3: Doesn't match indeterminate `<progress>` bars

css-indeterminate-pseudo.title: :indeterminate CSS pseudo-class

css-initial-value.description: A CSS value that will apply a property's initial value as defined in the CSS specification that defines the property
css-initial-value.title: CSS initial value

css-letter-spacing.description: Controls spacing between characters of text (i.e. "tracking" in typographical terms). Not to be confused with kerning.

notes_by_num.1: Truncates or rounds fractional portions of values

css-letter-spacing.title: letter-spacing CSS property

css-line-clamp.description: Proprietary and undocumented CSS property that will contain text to a given amount of lines when used in combination with `display: -webkit-box`. It will end with ellipsis when `text-overflow: ellipsis` is included.

links.title: Article on cross-browser CSS line clamping

css-line-clamp.notes:
As there is no specification and the property is dependent on an outdated implementation of flexbox (hence `display: -webkit-box`) it is unlikely that other browsers will support the property as-is, although an alternative solution may at some point replace it.

Older (presto-based) versions of the Opera browser have also supported the same effect using the proprietary `-o-ellipsis-lastline;` value for `text-overflow`.
css-line-clamp.title: CSS line-clamp

css-logical-props.description: Use start/end properties that depend on LTR or RTL writing direction instead of left/right

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the *-start, and *-end values for `margin`, `border` and `padding`, not the inline/block type values as defined in the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Like #1 but also supports `*-before` and `*-end` for `*-block-start` and `*-block-end` properties as well as `start` and `end` values for `text-align`

css-logical-props.title: CSS Logical Properties

css-masks.description: Method of displaying part of an element, using a selected image as a mask

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in WebKit/Blink browsers refers to supporting the mask-image and mask-box-image properties, but lacking support for other parts of the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Firefox refers to only support for inline SVG mask elements i.e. mask: url(#foo).

css-masks.title: CSS Masks

css-matches-pseudo.description: The `:matches()` (formerly `:any()`) pseudo-class checks whether the element at its position in the outer selector matches any of the selectors in its selector list. It's useful syntactic sugar that allows you to avoid writing out all the combinations manually as separate selectors. The effect is similar to nesting in Sass and most other CSS preprocessors.

links.title: WebKit blog post about adding `:matches()` and other Selectors Level 4 features
Mozilla Bug 906353 - Add support for css4 selector :matches(), the standard of :-moz-any()
Microsoft Edge UserVoice feature request for :matches()
Issue 568705: Chrome does not support :matches() selector

css-matches-pseudo.notes: Most browsers support this spelled as a prefixed `:-vendor-any()` pseudo-class.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the `:-webkit-any()` pseudo-class, which is deprecated due to handling specificity incorrectly.
notes_by_num.2: Also supports the `:-webkit-any()` pseudo-class, which is deprecated due to handling specificity incorrectly.
notes_by_num.3: Only supports the `:-moz-any()` pseudo-class.

css-matches-pseudo.title: :matches() CSS pseudo-class

css-media-interaction.description: Allows a media query to be set based on the presence and accuracy of the user's pointing device, and whether they have the ability to hover over elements on the page. This includes the `pointer`, `any-pointer`, `hover`, and `any-hover` media features.

links.title: Potential use cases for script, hover and pointer CSS Level 4 Media Features
Interaction Media Features and their potential (for incorrect assumptions)

css-media-interaction.title: Media Queries: interaction media features

css-media-resolution.description: Allows a media query to be set based on the device pixels used per CSS unit. While the standard uses `min`/`max-resolution` for this, some browsers support the older non-standard `device-pixel-ratio` media query.

links.title: WebKit Bug 78087: Implement the 'resolution' media query

notes_by_num.1: Supports the `dpi` unit, but does not support `dppx` or `dpcm` units.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox before 16 supports only `dpi` unit, but you can set `2dppx` per `min--moz-device-pixel-ratio: 2`
notes_by_num.3: Supports the non-standard `min`/`max-device-pixel-ratio`

css-media-resolution.title: Media Queries: resolution feature

css-mediaqueries.description: Method of applying styles based on media information. Includes things like page and device dimensions

notes_by_num.1: Does not support nested media queries
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only acknowledging different media rules on page reload

css-mediaqueries.title: CSS3 Media Queries

css-mixblendmode.description: Allows blending between arbitrary SVG and HTML elements

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial in Safari refers to not supporting the `hue`, `saturation`, `color`, and `luminosity` blend modes.

css-mixblendmode.title: Blending of HTML/SVG elements

css-motion-paths.description: Allows elements to be animated along SVG paths or shapes

notes_by_num.1: Requires the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag to be enabled

css-motion-paths.title: CSS Motion Path

css-not-sel-list.description: Selectors Level 4 allows the `:not()` pseudo-class to accept a list of selectors, which the element must not match any of. Selectors Level 3 only allowed `:not()` to accept a single simple selector. Thus, `:not(a):not(.b):not([c])` can instead be written as `:not(a, .b, [c])`
css-not-sel-list.title: selector list argument of :not()

css-nth-child-of.description: The newest versions of `:nth-child()` and `:nth-last-child()` accept an optional `of S` clause which filters the children to only those which match the selector list `S`. For example, `:nth-child(1 of .foo)` selects the first child among the children that have the `foo` class (ignoring any non-`foo` children which precede that child). Similar to `:nth-of-type`, but for arbitrary selectors instead of only type selectors.

links.title: Mozilla Bug 854148 - Support for :nth-child(An+B of sel), :nth-last-child(An+B of sel) pseudo-classes
Chromium Issue 304163: Implement :nth-child(an+b of S) and :nth-last-child(an+b of S) pseudo-classes

css-nth-child-of.title: selector list argument of :nth-child and :nth-last-child CSS pseudo-classes

css-opacity.description: Method of setting the transparency level of an element
css-opacity.notes: Transparency for elements in IE8 and older can be achieved using the proprietary "filter" property and does not work well with PNG images using alpha transparency.
css-opacity.title: CSS3 Opacity

css-optional-pseudo.description: The `:optional` pseudo-class matches form inputs (`<input>`, `<textarea>`, `<select>`) which are not `:required`.

notes_by_num.1: Does not match non-required `<select>`s

css-optional-pseudo.title: :optional CSS pseudo-class

css-page-break.description: Properties to control the way elements are broken across (printed) pages.

links.title: Latest fragmentation specification (includes column & region breaks)

css-page-break.notes: Not all mobile browsers offer print support; support listed for these is based on browser engine capability.

notes_by_num.1: Supports the `page-break-*` alias from the CSS 2.1 specification, but not the `break-*` properties from the latest spec.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `avoid` for `page-break-before` & `page-break-after` (only `page-break-inside`).
notes_by_num.3: Treats the `left` and `right` values like `always`.

css-page-break.title: CSS page-break properties

css-placeholder.description: The ::placeholder pseudo-element represents placeholder text in an input field: text that represents the input and provides a hint to the user on how to fill out the form. For example, a date-input field might have the placeholder text `YYYY/MM/DD` to clarify that numeric dates are to be entered in year-month-day order.

links.title: Mozilla Bug 1069012 - unprefix :placeholder-shown pseudo-class and ::placeholder pseudo-element

css-placeholder.notes:
Partial support refers to using alternate names:
`::-webkit-input-placeholder` for Chrome/Safari/Opera ([Chrome issue #623345](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=623345))
`:-ms-input-placeholder` for IE. 
`::-ms-input-placeholder` for Edge (also supports webkit prefix)

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 18 and below supported the `:-moz-placeholder` pseudo-class rather than the `::-moz-placeholder` pseudo-element.

css-placeholder.title: ::placeholder CSS pseudo-element

css-placeholder-shown.description: Input elements can sometimes show placeholder text as a hint to the user on what to type in. See, for example, the placeholder attribute in HTML5. The :placeholder-shown pseudo-class matches an input element that is showing such placeholder text.
css-placeholder-shown.notes: For support of styling the actual placeholder text itself, see [CSS ::placeholder](http://caniuse.com/#feat=css-placeholder)
css-placeholder-shown.title: :placeholder-shown CSS pseudo-class

css-reflections.description: Method of displaying a reflection of an element

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-reflections.notes: Similar effect can be achieved in Firefox 4+ using the -moz-element() background property
css-reflections.title: CSS Reflections

css-regions.description: Method of flowing content into multiple elements.

notes_by_num.1: Support is limited to using an iframe as a content source with the `-ms-flow-into: flow_name;` and `-ms-flow-from: flow_name;` syntax.

css-regions.title: CSS Regions

css-repeating-gradients.description: Method of defining a repeating linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.
css-repeating-gradients.notes: Firefox 10+, Chrome 26+ and Opera 11.6+ also support the new "to (side)" syntax.
css-repeating-gradients.title: CSS Repeating Gradients

css-resize.description: Method of allowing an element to be resized by the user, with options to limit to a given direction.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Presto-based Opera 12.10+ currently only supports the resize property for textarea elements.

css-resize.title: CSS resize property

css-revert-value.description: A CSS keyword value that resets a property's value to the default specified by the browser in its UA stylesheet, as if the webpage had not included any CSS. For example, `display:revert` on a `<div>` would result in `display:block`. This is in contrast to the `initial` value, which is simply defined on a per-property basis, and for `display` would be `inline`.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-revert-value.title: CSS revert value

css-scroll-behavior.description: Method of specifying the scrolling behavior for a scrolling box, when scrolling happens due to navigation or CSSOM scrolling APIs.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to support everything except of `Element.scrollIntoView()` and not together with pinch viewport.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Chrome and Opera behind the 'Smooth Scrolling' and/or 'Enable experimental web platform features' flag

css-scroll-behavior.title: CSSOM Scroll-behavior

css-scrollbar.notes: Currently scrollbar styling doesn't appear to be on any standards track.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports styling [scrollbar colors](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms531155%28v=vs.85%29.aspx), no other properties to define the scrollbar's appearance.
notes_by_num.2: Supports scrollbar styling via CSS [pseudo-properties](https://webkit.org/blog/363/styling-scrollbars/).

css-scrollbar.title: CSS scrollbar styling

css-sel2.description: Basic CSS selectors including: `*` (universal selector), `>` (child selector), `:first-child`, `:link`, `:visited`, `:active`, `:hover`, `:focus`, `:lang()`, `+` (adjacent sibling selector), `[attr]`, `[attr="val"]`, `[attr~="val"]`, `[attr|="bar"]`, `.foo` (class selector), `#foo` (id selector)
css-sel2.notes: Support for `:visited` styling [varies across browsers](http://sixrevisions.com/css/visited-pseudo-class-strange/) due to security concerns.
css-sel2.title: CSS 2.1 selectors

css-sel3.description: Advanced element selection using selectors including: `[foo^="bar"]`, `[foo$="bar"]`, `[foo*="bar"]`, `:root`, `:nth-child()`,  `:nth-last-child()`, `nth-of-type`, `nth-last-of-type()`, `:last-child`, `:first-of-type`, `:last-of-type`, `:only-child`, `:only-of-type`, `:empty`, `:target`, `:enabled`, `:disabled`, `:checked`, `:not()`, `~` (general sibling)

notes_by_num.1: IE7 and IE8 support only these CSS3 selectors: General siblings (`element1~element2`) and Attribute selectors `[attr^=val]`, `[attr$=val]`, and `[attr*=val]`

css-sel3.title: CSS3 selectors

css-selection.description: The ::selection CSS pseudo-element applies rules to the portion of a document that has been highlighted (e.g., selected with the mouse or another pointing device) by the user.
css-selection.title: ::selection CSS pseudo-element

css-shapes.description: Allows geometric shapes to be set in CSS to define an area for text to flow around.

links.title: CSS shapes support test by Adobe

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags

css-shapes.title: CSS Shapes Level 1

css-snappoints.description: CSS technique that allows customizable scrolling experiences like pagination of carousels by setting defined snap points.

links.title: MDN Documentation for CSS Scroll snap points

css-snappoints.notes: Works in the iOS WKWebView, but not UIWebView.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE10 refers to support limited to touch screens.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE11 [documented here](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/444684/openwebref/CSS/scroll-snap-points/support.html)
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.scroll-snap.enabled` flag in `about:config`
notes_by_num.4: Partial support in Safari refers to not supporting the `none` keyword in `scroll-snap-points-x`, `scroll-snap-points-y` and `scroll-snap-coordinate`, and length keywords (`top`, `right`, etc.) in `scroll-snap-destination` and `scroll-snap-coordinate`.

css-snappoints.title: CSS Scroll snap points

css-sticky.description: Keeps elements positioned as "fixed" or "relative" depending on how it appears in the viewport. As a result the element is "stuck" when necessary while scrolling.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference layout.css.sticky.enabled to true
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag

css-sticky.title: CSS position:sticky

css-supports-api.description: The CSS.supports() static methods returns a Boolean value indicating if the browser supports a given CSS feature, or not.

links.title: Native CSS Feature Detection via the @supports Rule

css-supports-api.notes:
See also [@supports in CSS](#feat=css-featurequeries)

See the [WebKit Bug](http://trac.webkit.org/changeset/142739) for status in Safari

notes_by_num.1: Opera 12 uses a different method name('window.supportsCSS')

css-supports-api.title: CSS.supports() API

css-table.description: Method of displaying elements as tables, rows, and cells. Includes support for all `display: table-*` properties as well as `display: inline-table`

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 2 does not support `inline-table`

css-table.title: CSS Table display

css-text-align-last.description: CSS property to describe how the last line of a block or a line right before a forced line break when `text-align` is `justify`.

notes_by_num.1: In Internet Explorer, the start and end values are not supported.
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in opera://flags

css-text-align-last.title: CSS3 text-align-last

css-text-justify.description: CSS property to define how text should be justified when `text-align: justify` is set.

notes_by_num.1: Supports `inter-word`, but not `inter-character` or  `none`. Also supports the following unofficial values: `distribute` , `distribute-all-lines`, `distribute-center-last`, `inter-cluster`, `inter-ideograph`, `newspaper`. See [MSDN](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms531172%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) for details.
notes_by_num.2: `inter-word` and `distribute` values supported behind the "Experimental platform features" flag but `distribute` support [is buggy](https://crbug.com/467406)

css-text-justify.title: CSS text-justify

css-textshadow.description: Method of applying one or more shadow or blur effects to text
css-textshadow.notes: Opera Mini ignores the blur-radius set, so no blur effect is visible. Text-shadow behavior can be somewhat emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "dropshadow" or "glow" filters.

notes_by_num.1: IE 10+ supports a fourth length value for the shadow's "spread". This is not (yet) part of the specification.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari 3.* refers to not supporting multiple shadows.

css-textshadow.title: CSS3 Text-shadow

css-touch-action.description: touch-action is a CSS property that controls filtering of gesture events, providing developers with a declarative mechanism to selectively disable touch scrolling (in one or both axes), pinch-zooming or double-tap-zooming.

links.title: What Exactly Is..... The 300ms Click Delay
What Exactly Is..... The 300ms Click Delay (Chinese)
WebKit bug 149854: Implement touch-action: manipulation; for iOS
WebKit bug 133112: touch-action CSS property support

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `layout.css.touch_action.enabled` flag, Firefox for Windows 8 Touch ('Metro') enabled by default.
notes_by_num.2: IE10+ has already supported these property which are not in standard at present such as'pinch-zoom','double-tap-zoom','cross-slide-x','cross-slide-y'.

css-touch-action.title: CSS touch-action property

css-transitions.description: Simple method of animating certain properties of an element, with ability to define property, duration, delay and timing function.

links.title: Animation of property types support in Opera

css-transitions.notes: Support listed is for `transition` properties as well as the `transitionend` event. The prefixed name in WebKit browsers is `webkitTransitionEnd`
css-transitions.title: CSS3 Transitions

css-unset-value.description: A CSS value that's the same as "inherit" if a property is inherited or "initial" if a property is not inherited.

links.title: WebKit bug 148614: Add support for the `unset` CSS property value

css-unset-value.title: CSS unset value

css-variables.description: Permits the declaration and usage of cascading variables in stylesheets.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in `chrome://flags`

css-variables.title: CSS Variables (Custom Properties)

css-widows-orphans.description: CSS properties to control when lines break across pages or columns by defining the amount of lines that must be left before or after the break.
css-widows-orphans.notes: Some older WebKit-based browsers recognize the properties, but do not appear to have actual support

notes_by_num.1: Supports widows & orphans properties, but due to not supporting CSS multi-columns the support is only for page breaks (for print)

css-widows-orphans.title: CSS widows & orphans

css-writing-mode.description: Property to define whether lines of text are laid out horizontally or vertically and the direction in which blocks progress.

notes_by_num.1: Internet Explorer supports different values from an [earlier version of the spec](http://www.w3.org/TR/2003/CR-css3-text-20030514/#Progression), which originated from SVG.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Firefox under the `layout.css.vertical-text.enabled` flag

css-writing-mode.title: CSS writing-mode property

links.title: Article explaining usage of zoom as the hack for fixing rendering bugs in IE6 and IE7.

css-zoom.notes: Originally implemented only in Internet Explorer. Although several other browsers support the property, using `transform: scale()` is the recommended solution to scale content.

notes_by_num.1: The `-ms-zoom` property is an extension to CSS, and can be used as a synonym for `zoom` in IE8 Standards mode.

css-zoom.title: CSS zoom

css3-attr.description: CSS Values and Units Level 3 adds the ability to use `attr()` on any CSS property, not just `content`, and to use it for non-string values (e.g. numbers, colors).

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
Mozilla Bug #435426: implement css3-values extensions to `attr()`
Chromium issue #246571: Implement CSS3 attribute / attr references
WebKit Bug #26609: Support CSS3 attr() function

css3-attr.title: CSS3 attr() function

css3-boxsizing.description: Method of specifying whether or not an element's borders and padding should be included in size units
css3-boxsizing.notes: Firefox currently also supports the `padding-box` in addition to `content-box` and `border-box`, though this value has been removed from the specification.
css3-boxsizing.title: CSS3 Box-sizing

css3-colors.description: Method of describing colors using Hue, Saturation and Lightness (hsl()) rather than just RGB, as well as allowing alpha-transparency with rgba() and hsla().
css3-colors.title: CSS3 Colors

css3-cursors.description: CSS3 cursor values added in the 2004 spec, including none, context-menu, cell, vertical-text, alias, copy, no-drop, not-allowed, nesw-resize, nwse-resize, col-resize, row-resize and all-scroll.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to no support for the alias, cell, copy, ew-resize, ns-resize, nesw-resize, nwse-resize or context-menu cursors.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting 'none'.

css3-cursors.title: CSS3 Cursors (original values)

css3-cursors-newer.description: Support for `zoom-in`, `zoom-out` values for the CSS3 `cursor` property.
css3-cursors-newer.title: CSS3 Cursors: zoom-in & zoom-out

css3-tabsize.description: Method of customizing the width of the tab character. Only effective using 'white-space: pre' or 'white-space: pre-wrap'.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Partial refers to supporting `<integer>` but not `<length>` values.

css3-tabsize.title: CSS3 tab-size

currentcolor.description: A CSS value that will apply the existing `color` value to other properties like `background-color`, etc.
currentcolor.title: CSS currentColor value

custom-elements.description: Method of defining and using new types of DOM elements in a document.

links.title: W3C Editor's Draft spec (closer to current implementations)
HTML5Rocks - Custom Elements: defining new elements in HTML
Chromium tracking bug: Implement Custom Elements
Firefox tracking bug: Implement Custom Elements (from Web Components)
IE Web Platform Status and Roadmap: Custom Elements

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "dom.webcomponents.enabled" preference in about:config

custom-elements.title: Custom Elements

customevent.description: A DOM event interface that can carry custom application-defined data.

links.title: Polyfill based on the MDN snippet
EventListener polyfill which includes a CustomEvent polyfill

customevent.notes: Not supported in some versions of Android's old WebKit-based WebView.

notes_by_num.1: While a `window.CustomEvent` object exists, it cannot be called as a constructor. Instead of `new CustomEvent(...)`, you must use `e = document.createEvent('CustomEvent')` and then `e.initCustomEvent(...)`
notes_by_num.2: There is no `window.CustomEvent` object, but `document.createEvent('CustomEvent')` still works.

customevent.title: CustomEvent

datalist.description: Method of setting a list of options for a user to select in a text field, while leaving the ability to enter a custom value.
datalist.notes: While most commonly used on text fields, datalists can also be used on other input types. IE11 supports the element on `range` fields. Chrome and Opera also support datalists to suggest given values on `range`, `color` and date/time fields.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to [a bug](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=375637) where long lists of items are unscrollable resulting in unselectable options.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to [significantly buggy behavior](http://playground.onereason.eu/2013/04/ie10s-lousy-support-for-datalists/) (IE11+ does send the input and change events upon selection).
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to no support for datalists on non-text fields (e.g. number, [range](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=841942), [color](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=960984)).

datalist.title: Datalist element

dataset.description: Method of applying and accessing custom data to elements.
dataset.notes:
Partial support refers to being able to use `data-*` attributes and access them using `getAttribute`. 

"Supported" refers to accessing the values using the `dataset` property. Current spec only refers to support on HTML elements, only some browsers also have support for SVG/MathML elements.

notes_by_num.1: While the HTML spec doesn't require it, these browsers also support `dataset` and `data-*` attributes on SVG elements, in compliance with [current plans for SVG2](http://www.w3.org/2015/01/15-svg-minutes.html#item03)

dataset.title: dataset & data-* attributes

datauri.description: Method of embedding images and other files in webpages as a string of text, generally using base64 encoding.

notes_by_num.1: Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS files, not HTML or JS files. Max URI length is 32KB.
notes_by_num.2: Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS or JS, not HTML files. Maximum size limit is 4GB.

datauri.title: Data URIs

details.description: The <details> element generates a simple no-JavaScript widget to show/hide element contents, optionally by clicking on its child <summary> element.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Firefox through the `dom.details_element.enabled` flag

details.title: Details & Summary elements

deviceorientation.description: API for detecting orientation and motion events from the device running the browser.
deviceorientation.notes: Partial support refers to the lack of compassneedscalibration event. Partial support also refers to the lack of devicemotion event support for Chrome 30- and Opera. Opera Mobile 14 lost the ondevicemotion event support. Firefox 3.6, 4 and 5 support the non-standard [MozOrientation](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/DOM/MozOrientation) event.

notes_by_num.1: `compassneedscalibration` supported in IE11 only for compatible devices with Windows 8.1+.

deviceorientation.title: DeviceOrientation & DeviceMotion events

devicepixelratio.description: Read-only property that returns the ratio of the (vertical) size of one physical pixel on the current display device to the size of one CSS pixel.
devicepixelratio.notes: As the page is zoomed in the number of device pixels that one CSS pixel covers increases, and therefore the value of devicePixelRatio will also increase.
devicepixelratio.title: Window.devicePixelRatio

dialog.description: Method of easily creating custom dialog boxes to display to the user with modal or non-modal options. Also includes a `::backdrop` pseudo-element for behind the element.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in `opera://flags`

dialog.title: Dialog element

dispatchevent.description: Method to programmatically trigger a DOM event.

notes_by_num.1: Supports Microsoft's proprietary [`EventTarget.fireEvent() method`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/fireEvent).

dispatchevent.title: EventTarget.dispatchEvent

document-currentscript.description: `document.currentScript` returns the `<script>` element whose script is currently being processed.
document-currentscript.title: document.currentScript

document-execcommand.description: Allows running commands to manipulate the contents of an editable region in a document switched to designMode
document-execcommand.notes: To determine what commands are supported, see `Document.queryCommandSupported()`
document-execcommand.title: Document.execCommand()

documenthead.description: Convenience property for accessing the `<head>` element
documenthead.title: document.head

dom-manip-convenience.description: jQuery-like methods on DOM nodes to insert nodes around or within a node, or to replace one node with another. These methods accept any number of DOM nodes or HTML strings as arguments. Includes: `ChildNode.before`, `ChildNode.after`, `ChildNode.replaceWith`, `ParentNode.prepend`, and `ParentNode.append`.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in chrome://flags

dom-manip-convenience.title: DOM manipulation convenience methods

dom-range.description: A contiguous range of content in a Document, DocumentFragment or Attr

links.title: "Rangy" Range library with old IE support

dom-range.title: Document Object Model Range

domcontentloaded.description: JavaScript event that fires when the DOM is loaded, but before all page assets are loaded (CSS, images, etc.).
domcontentloaded.title: DOMContentLoaded

download.description: When used on an anchor, this attribute signifies that the browser should download the resource the anchor points to rather than navigate to it.

links.title: Demo: creating a text file and downloading it.

download.title: Download attribute

dragndrop.description: Method of easily dragging and dropping elements on a page, requiring minimal JavaScript.

links.title: Microsoft Edge setDragImage feature request on UserVoice

dragndrop.notes:
`dataTransfer.items` only supported by Chrome.

Currently no browser supports the `dropzone` attribute.

Firefox supports any kind of DOM elements for `.setDragImage`. Chrome must have either an `HTMLImageElement` or any kind of DOM elements attached to the DOM and within the viewport of the browser for `.setDragImage`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to no support for the `dataTransfer.files` or `.types` objects
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `.setDragImage`
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to limited supported formats for `dataTransfer.setData`/`getData`.

dragndrop.title: Drag and Drop

element-closest.description: DOM method that returns the current element if it matches the given selector, or else the closest ancestor element that matches the given selector, or else null.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

element-closest.title: Element.closest()

eot.description: Type of font that can be derived from a regular font, allowing small files and legal use of high-quality fonts. Usage is restricted by the file being tied to the website
eot.notes: Proposal by Microsoft, being considered for W3C standardization.
eot.title: EOT - Embedded OpenType fonts

es5.description: Full support for the ECMAScript 5 specification. Features include `Function.prototype.bind`, Array methods like `indexOf`, `forEach`, `map` & `filter`, Object methods like `defineProperty`, `create` & `keys`, the `trim` method on Strings and many more.
es5.notes: As the specification includes many JavaScript features, un-numbered partial support varies widely and is shown in detail on the [ECMAScript 5 compatibilty tables](http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es5/) by Kangax.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `parseInt()` ignoring leading zeros.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support Strict mode
notes_by_num.3: Does not support zero-width chars in identifiers & Immutable `undefined`
notes_by_num.4: IE8 has virtually no ES5 support, but does support `Object.defineProperty`, `Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor`, JSON parsing & Property access on strings

es5.title: ECMAScript 5

es6-number.description: Extensions to the `Number` built-in object in ES6, including constant properties `EPSILON`, `MIN_SAFE_INTEGER`, and `MAX_SAFE_INTEGER`, and methods ` isFinite`, `isInteger`, `isSafeInteger`, and `isNaN`.

links.title: New number and Math features in ES6

notes_by_num.1: Partial refers to only supporting the `isFinite`, `isInteger`, and `isNaN` methods.
notes_by_num.2: Partial refers to supporting the same as #1 and the addition of the `EPSILON` property.
notes_by_num.3: Partial refers to supporting all new features except the `isSafeInteger` method.
notes_by_num.4: Partial refers to only supporting the `isFinite` and `isNaN` methods.

es6-number.title: ES6 Number

eventsource.description: Method of continuously sending data from a server to the browser, rather than repeatedly requesting it (EventSource interface, used to fall under HTML5)
eventsource.title: Server-sent events

notes_by_num.1: Partial support can be enabled in Firefox with the `dom.fetch.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Only available in Chrome and Opera within ServiceWorkers.
notes_by_num.3: Available in Chrome and Opera within Window and Workers by enabling the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.4: Firefox <40 is not completely conforming to the specs and does not respect the <base> tag for relative URIs in fetch requests. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1161625
notes_by_num.5: Appears to exist in Safari Technical Preview but does not work in current build. Should work in [next preview build](https://twitter.com/xeenon/status/715379838081576960)

fieldset-disabled.description: Allows disabling all of the form control descendants of a fieldset via a `disabled` attribute on the fieldset element itself.

notes_by_num.1: Text inputs that are descendants of a disabled fieldset appear disabled but the user can still interact with them. [See IE bug #962368.](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedbackdetail/view/962368/can-still-edit-input-type-text-within-fieldset-disabled)
notes_by_num.2: File inputs that are descendants of a disabled fieldset appear disabled but the user can still interact with them. [See IE bug #817488.](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedbackdetail/view/817488)

fieldset-disabled.title: disabled attribute of the fieldset element

fileapi.description: Method of manipulating file objects in web applications client-side, as well as programmatically selecting them and accessing their data.

notes_by_num.1: Does not have `FileReader` support.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `File` constructor

fileapi.title: File API

filereader.description: Method of reading the contents of a File or Blob object into memory

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `readAsBinaryString`

filereader.title: FileReader API

filereadersync.description: Allows files to be read synchronously in Web Workers
filereadersync.title: FileReaderSync

filesystem.description: Method of reading and writing files to a sandboxed file system.
filesystem.notes: The File API: Directories and System specification is no longer being maintained and support may be dropped in future versions.
filesystem.title: Filesystem & FileWriter API

flexbox.description: Method of positioning elements in horizontal or vertical stacks. Support includes the support for the all properties prefixed with `flex` as well as `display: flex`, `display: inline-flex`, `align-content`, `align-items`, `align-self`, `justify-content` and `order`.

links.title: Article on using the latest spec
Examples on how to solve common layout problems with flexbox
10up Open Sources IE 8 and 9 Support for Flexbox
Ecligrid - Mobile first flexbox grid system

flexbox.notes: Most partial support refers to supporting an [older version](http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-flexbox-20090723/) of the specification or an [older syntax](http://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-css3-flexbox-20120322/).

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the [old flexbox](http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-flexbox-20090723) specification and does not support wrapping.
notes_by_num.2: Only supports the [2012 syntax](http://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-css3-flexbox-20120322/)
notes_by_num.3: Does not support flex-wrap or flex-flow properties
notes_by_num.4: Partial support is due to large amount of bugs present (see known issues)

flexbox.title: Flexible Box Layout Module

focusin-focusout-events.description: The `focusin` and `focusout` events fire just before the element gains or loses focus, and they bubble. By contrast, the `focus` and `blur` events fire after the focus has shifted, and don't bubble.

links.title: focusin event at Mozilla Developer Network
focusout event at Mozilla Developer Network
Mozilla Bug 687787 - Add support for DOM3 focusin/focusout

focusin-focusout-events.notes: In browsers that don't support these events, one alternative is to use a capture phase event listener for the `focus` and/or `blur` events.
focusin-focusout-events.title: focusin & focusout events

font-feature.description: Method of applying advanced typographic and language-specific font features to supported OpenType fonts.

links.title: Syntax for OpenType features in CSS (Adobe Typekit Help)

font-feature.notes: Whenever possible, font-variant shorthand property or an associated longhand property, font-variant-ligatures, font-variant-caps, font-variant-east-asian, font-variant-alternates, font-variant-numeric or font-variant-position should be used. This property is a low-level feature designed to handle special cases where no other way to enable or access an OpenType font feature exists. In particular, this CSS property shouldn't be used to enable small caps.

notes_by_num.1: From Gecko 2.0 (Firefox 4.0) to Gecko 14.0 (Firefox 14.0) included, Gecko supported an older syntax, slightly different from the modern one: http://hacks.mozilla.org/2010/11/firefox-4-font-feature-support/
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older Chrome versions refers to lacking support in Mac OS X.

font-feature.title: CSS font-feature-settings

font-kerning.description: Controls the usage of the kerning information (spacing between letters) stored in the font. Note that this only affects OpenType fonts with kerning information, it has no effect on other fonts.
font-kerning.notes: Browsers with support for [font feature settings](http://caniuse.com/#feat=font-feature) can also set kerning value.

notes_by_num.1: Disabled by default, can be enabled using preference layout.css.font-features.enabled - defaulting to true on Nightly and Aurora only.

font-kerning.title: CSS3 font-kerning

font-loading.description: This CSS module defines a scripting interface to font faces in CSS, allowing font faces to be easily created and loaded from script. It also provides methods to track the loading status of an individual font, or of all the fonts on an entire page.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.font-loading-api.enabled` flag. Enabled by default in Firefox 41. See [this bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1149381)

font-loading.title: CSS Font Loading

font-size-adjust.description: Method of adjusting the font size in a matter that relates to the height of lowercase vs. uppercase letters. This makes it easier to set the size of fallback fonts.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Does not appear to work on Firefox mobile, despite recognition of the property.

font-size-adjust.title: CSS font-size-adjust

font-smooth.description: Controls the application of anti-aliasing when fonts are rendered.

links.title: Old version of W3C recommendation containing font-smooth

font-smooth.notes: Though present in early (2002) drafts of CSS3 Fonts, `font-smooth` has been removed from this specification and is currently not on the standard track.

notes_by_num.1: Webkit implements something similar with a different name `-webkit-font-smoothing` and different values: `none`, `antialiased` and `subpixel-antialiased`.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox implements something similar with a different name `-moz-osx-font-smoothing` and different values: `auto`, `inherit`, `unset`, `grayscale`.
notes_by_num.3: Works only on Mac OS X platform.

font-smooth.title: CSS font-smooth

font-unicode-range.description: This @font-face descriptor defines the set of Unicode codepoints that may be supported by the font face for which it is declared. The descriptor value is a comma-delimited list of Unicode range (<urange>) values. The union of these ranges defines the set of codepoints that serves as a hint for user agents when deciding whether or not to download a font resource for a given text run.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

font-unicode-range.notes: Partial support indicates that unnecessary code-ranges are downloaded by the browser - see [browser test matrix](https://docs.google.com/a/chromium.org/spreadsheets/d/18h-1gaosu4-KYxH8JUNL6ZDuOsOKmWfauoai3CS3hPY/edit?pli=1#gid=0).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.unicode-range.enabled` flag

font-unicode-range.title: Font unicode-range subsetting

font-variant-alternates.description: Controls the usage of alternate glyphs associated to alternative names defined in @font-feature-values for certain types of OpenType fonts.

notes_by_num.1: Low-level syntax available in [font-feature-settings](http://caniuse.com/#feat=font-feature) property equivalent to OpenType features: salt, ss01 through ss20, cv01 through cv99, swsh, cswh, ornm, nalt
notes_by_num.2: Experimental support available by enabling the layout.css.font-features.enabled flag

font-variant-alternates.title: CSS font-variant-alternates

fontface.description: Method of displaying fonts downloaded from websites
fontface.notes: Not supported by IE Mobile 9 and below.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting EOT fonts.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only supporting SVG fonts.

fontface.title: @font-face Web fonts

form-attribute.description: Attribute for associating input and submit buttons with a form.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

form-attribute.title: Form attribute

form-validation.description: Method of setting required fields and field types without requiring JavaScript. This includes preventing forms from being submitted when appropriate, the `checkValidity()` method as well as support for the `:invalid`, `:valid`, and `:required` CSS pseudo-classes.
